description: Recently completed library and community space, located at the heart of the regeneration of Thamesmead, on Cygnet Square, just off Harrow Manor Way in South Thamesmead.

events.name: Fun Activities in Cygnet Square
events.notes: Join local artists, just outside The Nest in Cygnet Sqaure for a range of interactive and creative activities celebrating Thamesmead’s unique architectural character and heritage. The People Speak’s infamous Talkaoke pop-up talk show will be back hosting round table discussions for anyone to have their say and discuss what matters to them. There will also be local food providers and music to keep you entertained throughout the afternoonVisitors can arrive at any time during the opening hours.There may be queues at busy times.

events.name: Architect Led Tours of The Nest Civic and Library Building
events.notes: Architects Bisset Adams and the team leading the regeneration in Thamemead from Peabody will be leading tours of The Nest, before its opening later this year.

events.name: Architect Led Tours of The Nest Civic and Library Building
events.notes: Architects Bisset Adams and the team leading the regeneration in Thamemead from Peabody will be leading tours of The Nest, before its opening later this year.

events.name: Tours of Show Flats in Southmere
events.notes: We are offering tours of the new show flats overlooking The Nest and Cygnet Square. Grab this opportunity to have a look around the flagship apartments recently completed as part of the regeneration of South Thamesmead. Tours are every 15 minutes and are first come,first served.

facilities: Family activities during open house festival

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: Thamesmead Stage One was built in the late sixties and was intended to provide housing of the future for those who currently lived in cramped and run down conditions within Inner London. First designed and built by the GLC, these properties were to be futuristic and forward thinking homes for those who needed it most.

Built on marshlands on what was old Royal Arsenal Land, Thamesmead  was a self-contained city in the sky, with its elevated walkways, man-made lakes and expansive green areas, it felt like such a contrast from the cramped and damp conditions of inner London.

Despite some undoubted successes, a lack of investment and infrastructure has meant that Thamesmead is yet to fully to live up to initial potential. However, just over 50 years after its creation, with investment of over £1 billion now coming in, Thamesmead is now well set to fulfil its promise as London's new town.
The Southmere development, where The Nest takes it's central position on the main square, is at the heart of what was stage one and forms part of Peabody's investment in Thamesmead.

factsheet.heading: Peabody
paragraphs: When Peabody incorporated Thamesmead's three leading organisations in 2014, it meant that much of the town's housing, community investment activities and over 200 acres of developable land became owned by a single, well-resourced body for the first time in a generation.

As Thamesmead’s main landowner, Peabody is driving the town's regeneration in collaboration with partners. Thamesmead is one of Peabody's core priorities, and a dedicated Thamesmead regeneration team has been built up to deliver the ambitious vision for change in the town.

Peabody is one of London's oldest and largest housing associations and has been creating opportunities for Londoners since 1862 when it was established by the American banker and philanthropist, George Peabody. Its mission is to ensure that as many people as possible have a good home, a real sense of purpose and a strong feeling of belonging.

Housing associations, Peabody and Family Mosaic merged to create a new Peabody in July 2017. Working across 21 locations in London and the South East, we own and manage more than 55,000 homes, providing affordable housing for around 111,000 people.

factsheet.heading: The Nest - A NEW CIVIC & LIBRARY BUILDING FOR THE COMMUNITY
paragraphs:
The design of the new Civic &
Library building at Southmere
is the result of an RIBA
competition which was won by
Bisset Adams.
The building is set over two
floors with an additional
mezzanine level. The new
library will be located on the
ground floor offering a variety
of study areas in addition to a
cafe, meeting rooms, childrens
library and IT suite. The first
floor provides a multi-purpose
space which could provide
facilities such as toddler
groups, local clubs and yoga.
This is supported by further
community spaces on the
mezzanine level which 
include a health room.
The library space is
predominantly glazed to create
views both into and out of
the building and to make the
interior spaces feel connected
to the surrounding landscape.
The flexible, multi-use space
above the main library space is
orientated differently from the
base of the building, rotated
to face over Southmere Lake
for the fantastic views and to
reflect the irregular form of a
Swan’s nest.
A wild flower green roof and
sky light provides visual
amenity for the neighbouring
residents and helps to increase
biodiversity.
